bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, October 26, 1910

div1.p: Carter describes his travels in Germany and Russia.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, October 26, 1910
div1.opener:
Hôtel de St. Petersbourg
LIBAU.
Oct 26/10
Dear (Mis;) Laura:
div1.p:
I ought not to write from Libau until I
reach Berlin. Then I could tell you better about it.
I reached it yester morning at 7.40 - although it
was quite dark. It is also fairly dark by 4.30 P. M.
It is not very cold - but freezing every night & just
freezing during the day. I see no ice during the day
but the thermometer registered 32° the last two
nights & at 4. P. M today. It is cloudy with grey
low hung clouds & damp - raw, but not windy
Particularly cheerless looking, & yet, except that the cab
men look cold, everyone else looks. I presume a-
bout as usual. Not much expression in their faces,
a rather hopeless, but not unhappy look.

I got on very well on the trip - 2 fairly pleasant
plesant companions, a German 35 years in En-
gland - an art dealer - & a German a very short
time in England, but speaking some En-
glish - a decent went with me from Hanno-
ver - to Berlin - I struck the main line &
changed cars at Hanover. Had a decent night
in the “schlaf-wagon” - Berlin to Koningbeng.
At the Russian Frontier it was a nuisance
but only a nuisance - paid 75 cts to get out
& puzzled an English man by remarking
that “if that was all they wanted I would have
paid 3 roubles” - $1.50) “not to have gone in”.
In attempting to explain to me that the 75 cts
was possibly not the sole reasons for the
ex customs inspection & the Passport he rec'd
back
another man's passport - Allison's, (his name
was Atkinson) & I left him stuggeling
with that difficulty.

From the frontier on I shared the compart-
ment with a very pleasant Russian fami-
ly - a Vice Admiral, who was at Port Arthur
in the beginning of the war - his wife &
daughter. The latter two spoke English
& the Admiral French, so we had a
very interesting time. I was able to
keep anyone else out of their compart-
ment - on 4 allowed in - until about 9.40
o'clock - when I left it to take the Libau train
& it was so late then that there was an ex-
cellent chance that they had it to them-
selves the balance of the night - to Riga
The had lived in Vladivostock - 2 1/2 years & were de-
cidedly interesting. The Old lady - who did most
of the talking - was a decided “reactionary”
& told me with horror of the “revolution”
as she called in in Kovno - the province then
which we were passing & in which her brother
lived. The Daughter - not a young girl, but
a very pleasant one & whose precise, & not
always correct, English were a Joy to
hear, was decidedly more liberal - as I
think was her father. He said little on
the subject however but to whom she con-
tinually appealed as if he had been in
the habit of agreeing with her. There was gen-
eral agreement however, myself inclusive, to the
old ladys statement that “Russia was
not yet ready to be a republic” with
which she appeared very well satisfied.

After leaving Koshadang-where In my own com-
partment - next to theirs, was a Russian who
spoke about as much German I do - unfortu-
nately not exactly the same German - who
was selling Typewriting machines - the
W W Underwood - which he prounced with a “W”
He had been to Moscow & to Oranburg & had sold
123 this year ($140 to $10 $187.50 a piece)
Had sold 5 to the Bureau of Accounts of
Russia - but had given them "3 years
credit!! It was a machine which
used Russian letters - of which there
are either 32 or 36 - & some remarkable
ones two. He reminded me much
of the Am. Drummer in “the Shuttle”
& we affiliated as much as the limited
vocabulary we held in common al-
lowed.

There was no light in the compartment - ex-
cept one candle over the door - & he had a
small stock of candles, & gave me one to give
the ladies to take their tea by. They thanked
went over - the young one - & thanked him & they
talked - (all three) as easily as if they had been of
the same class. you I it It is like it was in
Va. in old times. Class distinction is
Hôtel de St. Petersbourg
LIBAU.
clearly recognized that no attempt is made
to preserve it - none being necessary. I said
all three - the Admiral was out getting a reg-
ular supper. On the whole it was a pleas-
ant instead of a boring Journey, I take no-
thing to read on the train with me as this
keeps me looking at the country & seeing
people, & I can read on my return. Probably
however it will be advisable to buy a book - French
for I will read it more slowly - for my sea trip
back.

Now the last thing. I have bought - for & O. R.
18 Roubles =$9.00- a Oranbourg shawl. It is an
open-work all wool affair very fine & pretty
Far finer than- but not at pretty alas-as the Breton
shawls at Cherbourg - It is a good big thing &
it will go through a finger ring - I saw
him do it. I doubt if it has any warmth in it, it is
too light & probably is meant more for the head
than to really wear. I got him for your mother
but & it will do if I no better can do - but I am
still on the look out for something for her
at once pretty (artistic) & useful - like
the Breton shawls - This is distinctive-
i.e. Russian - rather than very pretty or at all
useful. It is pretty same however from its finess. I have to pay duty on all thing
not for personal wear “not personal wear-
ing apparel or for personal adornment”
including “presents to friends” & so I will
declare it. My dealer said it would
not be necessary as it could be worn
under the shirt, or even in the hat if one was
careful not to take it off or in an inside
pocket!!

Also I lost my Cap = 50 cents: No sleepers on the
train to Libau - but good long seats & very comfort-
able - I lay with it over my face - a very good night-
& when I woke up it had fallen off & I forgot it.

I have lost only one umbrella the one I started with-
since I have been over & am going to try to hold
on to my English one,- thought I had lost that
yesterday but I had not.

I judge that I will leave Libau tomorrow night.
3 days stay or Friday afternoon, then a
few days in Berlin: 1 to 2 in Hamburg
thence to Bremen - then report my work
is done by cable & then I expect - the N. D. Lloyd
s. s. for N. Y - about the 10 may be the 14 th
If I had a plenty of money I would ask
for 14 days leave & go to Italy & see Geddings
but I it is the cholera work at Naples I would
go to see not Italy., so you have no excuse
to advise me to do so anyway.

Good night - Love to your mother & to Sally
& to the Heplers & Dr Ritter. Why in
the Deuce didn't you make up the ne-
cessary & appropriate messages to give the
H's & R. without awaiting them - They
are sent in intention
